narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Titus and Sveta provided an exemplary introduction into Russian language and culture. I gained a firm understanding of five Russian cases, a wide span or vocabulary, and fascinating cultural connections.
Basic familiarity with the Russian language
I developed an understanding of basic Russian grammar, limited vocabulary, and heightened understanding of Russian culture.
I learned how to speak, read, write, and type Russian at a beginner's level.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall an excellent, well organized Course. Professor Titus does an excellent job teaching, cares a lot, and keeps the class rolling at a good, fast pace.

Professor Titus has a warm and welcoming personality that embodies a spirit of learning. This atmosphere alone provided an exceptional and engaging environment in which to learn a language, even with the online

Titus is quite an enjoyable and entertaining professor definitely a strength! The largest weakness was the virtual format; it's not easy learning a language (especially pronunciation) over Zoom. Hopefully, this won't be an issue for next fall!
The course was very good at keeping students engaged, especially given the current situation. The course was also very good for knowledge retention.

I couldn't justify identifying a weakness in this course. I believe that, given the circumstances, Julia Titus and the rest of the Russian department maximized resources to enhance the learning environment.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: About as good as it can get -- fortunately, many of Professor Titus's assessments were already geared towards a digital format. It was sometimes an annoying process to see homework feedback, but that was more of a canvas quirk than anything.
The Zoom format was not as intrusive as I had figured it would be. I do not see an area for improvement.
Learning Russian over Zoom made it a particularly challenging endeavour. The teaching team did the best they could, though this is a hard problem to get around in this case.

Among the courses I took this term, this one transitioned to virtual learning the most smoothly. The basic format of the course was quite successful, as were the tests and quizzes. The course was also helped by the breakout room feature, although it still would have been better in person.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! The Russian program seems to be well run at Yale, and learning a language fundamentally distinct from English is a cool sort of challenge and interesting process.
Absolutely. Russian has many geopolitical and social uses, and the quality of instruction from this course is outstanding.

Recommending this course really means recommending you learn the Russian language. If you would like to, this is a great way to do it!  If you would like to learn a language, but aren't quite sure which, here are some notes: Russian has been much harder than other languages I've studied; Russia and its associated countries have deep and rich histories and cultures; at times, this class can feel very quick-paced. In sum, if you're looking for a linguistic challenge, I recommend giving Russian a shot.
Absolutely! This was an excellent course for anyone who wants to learn Russian.
Absolutely.
